markdownRemark.html:
Score: 100

businessinsider.com  (WEB - en-US)

A site focused on business news that also covers politics, technology, sports, and lifestyle.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

German digital media company Axel Springer SE is the majority owner of Insider Inc., the private, New York-based company that operates businessinsider.com and the site’s international editions. Insider Inc. relies on several sources of revenue: advertisements on its sites; subscription fees for “Business Insider Prime;” sponsored posts; sponsorship of Ignition (its annual conference about media and technology); and subscription fees for Business Insider Intelligence, its financial research and reporting site.

Content

The site runs stories and opinion pieces about business and finance, as well as about politics, technology, the media, and lifestyle trends. It features original reporting and includes aggregated content from other news organizations.

Many stories are designed for quick digestion, featuring bullet point summaries or a format using lists (“The top 30 companies where Ivy League graduates who studied computer science say they most want to work.”) The site also publishes longer stories and in-depth reports, often with attention-grabbing headlines (“Google used to ask these interview questions, but they're so tricky they were banned.”)

Business Insider sometimes breaks news, as it did in an exclusive report revealing how much money and material Tesla wasted in its production of its Model 3 cars. Some articles, marked as “BI Prime,” are restricted to paid subscribers.

Credibility

Articles on the site reflect original reporting and interviewing, and also source information from other news outlets. Content is fact-based, and headlines fairly reflect the articles they describe. The site’s policy is to append corrections at the end of stories if errors or omissions “meaningfully change the story.”

Transparency

Businessinsider.com discloses its ownership by Axel Springer on an About page. Its Contact Us page includes biographies and email addresses for its staff, in addition to central email addresses for general inquiries. Articles name the author and link to his or her biography and contact information. Some authors write disclosures in biographies listing potential conflicts of interest. Opinion content is labeled as “opinion,” and advertisements are labeled. The site publishes a disclaimer if it receives a commission from products it reviewed, stating: “Business Insider has affiliate partnerships, so we get a share of the revenue from your purchase.”

History

Henry Blodget, a former Wall Street analyst, and Dwight Merriman and Kevin Ryan, former executives of advertising company DoubleClick, founded the site, initially called “Silicon Alley Insider,” in 2007. Earlier, Blodget had been barred for life from the securities industry after violating securities law. In 2015, Axel Springer SE purchased a majority stake in the site. 

Disclosure: NewsGuard co-CEO Gordon Crovitz was an investor in, and is a board member of, Business Insider.

Written by:
Sarah Brandt

Edited by:
Jim Warren Joyce Purnick
